page.title: 18Bredwardine; Housing.
page.content: The nearby 'Arthur's Stone', an ancient burial chamber, indicates very long-standing settlement. Some old cottages, still in use, were built of rounded stones from stream-beds, and rough stones from the fields, jointed only with clay; these may well outdate the Norman churches and cottages built with dressed stones. In Tudor times timber-framed buildings came into use and in the Victorian era many cottages were 'modernised' with a brick facing. In the middle of the present century houses were built of brick and concrete blocks. Some of the old cottages have been extended, but no new houses have been built in the last 20 years. Although there are relatively few dwellings in the area, they illustrate the variety of house- building methods in use over many centuries.
